questions.question_text: Which three statements are true about Global Resource Management in an Oracle 12c RAC database?

discussion.content:
In my opinion ACD:
A and D - both are treated as gracefully shutdown
C - Not all resources are remastered, only that which have shadow metadata on survived nodes

choices.B: Object remastering causes all blocks in any instances’ buffer cache from the same object to be mastered in the Global Resource Directory (GRD).
choices.C: When a database instance fails, then some global resource masters lost from the failing instance are remastered among the surviving instances.
choices.E: Global Enqueue resources are recovered after Global Cache Resources after an instance failure.
choices.A: Lazy remastering occurs when an instance shuts with SHUTDOWN IMMEDIATE.
choices.D: Lazy remastering instances occurs when an instance shuts with SHUTDOWN TRANSACTIONAL.

questions.answer_description:
B: Remastering is the term used that describes the operation whereby a node attempting recovery tries to own or master the resource(s) that were once mastered by another instance prior to the failure. When one instance leaves the cluster, the GRD of that instance needs to be redistributed to the surviving nodes. RAC uses an algorithm called lazy remastering to remaster only a minimal number of resources during a reconfiguration.
D: Using the SHUTDOWN TRANSACTIONAL command with the LOCAL option is useful to shut down a particular Oracle RAC database instance. Transactions on other instances do not block this operation.
C: Recovery from instance failure is automatic, requiring no DBA intervention. In case of instance failure, a surviving instance can read the redo logs of the failed instance.
For example, when using the Oracle Parallel Server, another instance performs instance recovery for the failed instance. In single-instance configurations, Oracle performs crash recovery for a database when the database is restarted, that is, mounted and opened to a new instance. The transition from a mounted state to an open state automatically triggers crash recovery, if necessary.
Incorrect Answers:
A: After a NORMAL or IMMEDIATE shutdown, instance recovery is not required.
References:
https://docs.oracle.com/database/121/RACAD/admin.htm#RACAD8910

choices.A: ASM files created using an alias name are not OMF files even if OMF is enabled.
choices.D: Alias names can be stored only in user-defined directories.
choices.C: ASM files created using an alias name are OMF files even if OMF is not enabled.
choices.B: Alias file names cannot be used together with templates when creating tablespaces.
choices.E: ASM files created using an alias name also have a fully qualified name and can be accessed by either name.

questions.question_text: Which two statements are true about ASM alias names?

discussion.content:
According Oracle Docs such as bellow doc, correct answer are A and E.
https://docs.oracle.com/database/121/OSTMG/GUID-2D167F11-F77A-4269-967E-5A9F3EF8FE3A.htm#OSTMG94202

questions.answer_description:
C: Server pools divide the cluster into logical groups of servers hosting both singleton and uniform applications. The application can be a database service or a non-database application.
D: You manage server pools that contain Oracle RAC databases with the Server Control (SRVCTL) utility.
E: When Oracle Clusterware is installed, two internal server pools are created automatically: Generic and Free. All servers in a new installation are assigned to the

Free server pool, initially -
References:
https://docs.oracle.com/database/121/CWADD/pbmgmt.htm#CWADD92594

choices.C: The server pool contains servers that host administrator-defined high availability resources.
choices.E: All servers in a new cluster installation belong to the free server pool.
choices.D: Server pools must be managed with the srvctl utility for servers hosting a database.
choices.B: All servers in a new cluster installation belong to the generic server pool.
choices.A: Server Pools must be managed with the crsctl utility for servers hosting an application or other administrator-defined high-availability resource.

questions.question_text: Which three statements are true concerning policy-based cluster management in Oracle 12c Clusterware?

discussion.content:
Why A is incorrect? 
According with this link this should be correct, not?
https://docs.oracle.com/database/121/CWADD/GUID-4473E9CE-8431-47E3-90F6-06181BA5A906.htm#CWADD00100

"Database administrators use the Server Control (SRVCTL) utility to create and manage server pools that will contain Oracle RAC databases. Cluster administrators use the Oracle Clusterware Control (CRSCTL) utility to create and manage all other server pools, such as server pools for non-database applications. Only cluster administrators have permission to create top-level server pools."
Do not use the CRSCTL command on Oracle entities with names that start with ora (resources, resource types, server pools, etc.) unless instructed by My Oracle Support.

choices.E: The Clusterware stack must be up on all cluster nodes.
choices.C: SSH user equivalence for the Oracle software owner must be configured on all cluster nodes where the Database Software will be installed.
choices.D: Grid infrastructure must be installed on all cluster nodes.
choices.B: Grid infrastructure must be installed on all cluster nodes where the Database software will be installed.
choices.A: SSH user equivalence for the Oracle software owner must be configured on all cluster nodes.

questions.question_text: Which two tasks must be performed before launching the Oracle universal installer to install Oracle Database Software for RAC?

comments.content: C is not true, because we can configure the user equivalence in OUI.

discussion.content: B and C are correct answers, because these two task must be done on the nodes where Oracle Software will install not on all available nodes. May be you want to select specific nodes for installation amongst your nodes.
A and C of course no; it's a RAC database patchset, GI it's not affected

questions.question_text:
You plan to apply a patchset to a RAC database running on a two-node cluster.
✑ The cluster has this configuration:
✑ Grid infrastructure release 12.1.0.1.0
✑ RAC database release 12.1.0.1.0
✑ All software installed on local file systems
✑ The database is deployed on ASM disk groups.
Examine this list of possible tasks (see exhibit).
Exhibit:
//IMG//

Identify the required tasks in the correct order to apply the patchset with the least amount of down time.
